job_title: Customer Service Representative in Wakefield, England
pros: Company benefits Friendly atmosphere Free Parking Good Salary Having worked for City & Guilds for the past 5 years I can honestly say that I've never worked anywhere that makes you feel like you are actually part of the bigger picture. Where what you do makes a difference regardless of your role. Career progression has always been important to me and I find that I can always approach anyone within senior management who will have time to sit and discuss career aspirations, they encourage and give the support needed as well as any training which will help me progress within my career with City & Guilds. I find the office to be friendly and fun, all colleagues are approachable regardless of their role or title. Everyone is encouraged to take part in any charity fund raisers, work related holiday events or office get togethers. We're not just a team, we're like a family. We celebrate everything and everyone. Working here has always felt positive for me.
cons: Nothing other than the possibility of more parking spaces.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Wakefield, England
pros: Use of SAP, Mon-Fri hours, free parking
cons: 1) Awful training (basically 2 trainers going through a bunch of Powerpoint presentations quickly yet was extremely light for the complex job itself) 2) Toxic environment- the place was very cliquey in the sense that if you did one thing wrong you will be singled out and slated behind your back and in some instances not even invited to work nights out for example Christmas Parties! 3) Poor management- Senior managers often locked themselves away in a separate office and couldn't care less about what was going on in the Call Centre itself and only emerged if they wanted coffee/tea. 4) Grumpy Team Leaders- don't get me wrong not all were grumpy but if you asked a question that you didn't know the answer to they would look at you as if you were stupid and in some instances get silly remarks. 5) Unrealistic standards- the job itself is very complex in the sense that you are expected to know a wide variety of modules in a short space of time and if you don't meet quality standards you will be in trouble. 6) It's a proven fact that nobody passes probation after 6 months- I know people who were there 4/5 years and they said that no matter how well an individual has done in the job their probation will always be extended for a month for any given excuse. 7) Busybody workmates who are not afraid to grass if you have done something minor very wrong and report immediately to the Team Leaders instead of you. 8) Micro-managing Team Leaders- they would go through every little detail such as timing toilet breaks, wrap time, interactions etc. The times I knew people who were dragged into the office for these things was embarrassing it was like being back at school.

pros: Decent wage and benefits. Competitive bonus structure and option to buy and sell annual leave. Since lockdown, the ability to work from home.

If you want to progress in the company it's very much about whether your face fits and not if you have the skills to perform well which had been demonstrated time and time again. A lot of false promises and decisions made without consulting employees and just expecting you to go with whatever is decided without objection. Following lockdown, the pressures did not improve nor did the level of support received, in fact it got worse. Not the first  employee to get fed up and leave then move onto better things and definitely won't be the last. Left due to deteriorating mental health as a result of stress, lack of training for the most recent role I took within the company and was topped off by my deeply inappropriate and incompetent manager who wouldn't listen to me but would often fill my day with barking orders at me and the team with little to no explanation or guidance on how to fulfill said orders. Would seriously avoid this company if you value your sanity. You would be better off claiming benefit than working here. If I had to sum up the last 6-9 months of my employment here I would describe it as an uninspiring, mentally draining ordeal riddled with passive aggressive, unhelpful managers and changes to business and job roles, which can only be described as disorganised chaos.

job_title: Head of Department in London, England
pros: City & Guilds does a great job for its learners and especially those who find the 'traditional' route of gaining qualifications challenging.  Its a fantastic brand to have on your CV, the office facilities are good, the benefits likewise, and generally people enjoy the work that they are doing because it is so worthwhile.
cons: The leadership has lost the plot.  It's all powerpoint slides and spreadsheets.  I don't think the guy who runs it really understands the business at all.  There's little stability in the senior team, they seem to get fired with surprising regularity. And direction doesn't really cascade into the organisation.  This is a shame, because under a previous Director General, it was all very different.  He was approachable, seen about the offices, clearly knew his stuff, and was a recognised authority used by governments and others as an expert.  You felt you knew where you were going and it was very rewarding.  The successive reorganisations seem to have eroded the sense of mission and purpose in the top team.  I think they have forgotten this is one of UK's biggest charities and it has a social justice agenda in education.  They only seem interested in making money.

Many senior managers talk a lot but don't actually say much.  Waffle and sound bites!

Kindness viewed almost as a weakness.

Redundancy programmes every couple of years without fail.

Job roles cut so workload builds up on staff who remain.  Leads to high levels of stress.  Staff taking sick leave due to work pressures.

Company is a charity although CEO and senior staff share millions in bonuses - justify it by saying "need to retain top talent" which is self-serving BS.  Many people could do the top jobs if given the access and opportunity.

Kirstie Donnelly's presentations are like a cross between Alan Partridge and David Brent.

review_title: Sad to see this decline in a once great organisation
cons:
This was an awful company to work for. It took me a couple of years to restore my mental health.

There are many longstanding members of staff that date from an age where C&G were worldwide 'experts' in vocational training. Now they are worldwide providers but have only tiny pockets of expertise. Staff training is poor and ineffectively targeted so practises are outdated. Dinosaur is the term they sort to shake off when I worked there. They strived to do this through boosts to Information Technology, forfeiting quality and undermining staff and teams involved with robust assessment along the way. There is little understanding of the fundamental nature of the Business and many Government initiatives [that might have had better success] have fallen because this organisation was turned to for direction. Riding on 'merit from long ago' has served them well, but how long can this go on for. I saw a part of their demise as they were forced to make a series of redundancies and sold off buildings in Guiltspur St to stay afloat, when they should have been thriving - if only they had better knowledge of the job.
The Senior Management Team seemed the main problem. Induction and recruitment processes were very poor. As a result turnover was fast and existing staff members frequently failed to greet or acknowledge new staff members. There could as a result be a strangely cold atmosphere given the large number of staff in the building. Insufficient attempt to help staff understand the various parts of the business, role requirements, or how things got done. Staff talent was definitely wasted left, right and centre.
Institutional racism was rampant, with many aggrieved BAME staff. Lots of Black women in admin and cleaning roles and lots of people of colour in adverts. Senior Management was very 'white' and showed little understanding when challenged around the organisations statistics. A general attitude of 'if I can get into the Snr Team as a white working class man or a white lesbian woman' then anybody can do it :-/
